awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Sarah Peluse is " Quantitative bounds in the polynomial and multidimensional Szemeredi theorem and other topics in additive combinatorics". The host institution for the fellowship is Oxford University and the sponsoring scientist is Ben Green.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The University of Oxford, Mathematical Institute

por.por_cntn:
The PI's primary research interests are in additive combinatorics and analytic number theory, and the NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship supported the PI's work on a wide variety of projects. Within the realm of additive combinatorics, the PI proved the first quantitative bounds in the polynomial Szemerédi theorem for arbitrarily long distinct degree polynomial progressions, obtained (joint with Prendiville) improved bounds in the nonlinear Roth theorem, proved (joint with Krause, Mirek, and Wright) the first quantitative version of the polynomial Szemerédi theorem in topological fields for distinct degree polynomial progressions, proved (joint with Sah and Sawhney) the first reasonable bounds for subsets of the integers lacking three-term arithmetic progressions with shifted square common difference, and proved reasonable bounds in the multidimensional Szemerédi theorem for the first ever genuinely multidimensional four-point configuration in the finite field model setting. In the realm of analytic number theory, the PI proved an "almost all" version of the prime power conjecture for cyclic projective planes, and resolved (joint with Soundararajan) several conjectures of Miller on the divisibility properties of typical entries in character tables of symmetric groups. This resulted in nine papers and preprints. The PI also wrote two expository articles and co-organized a weekly virtual seminar on additive combinatorics (with accompanying YouTube channel) during the COVID-19 pandemic.


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Sarah Peluse
